title: Why Not R
description: Why not use R for all courses in Commerce (BComm and MBA)?
contents:
It is my belief that a business studentâ€™s academic journey can be
enriched by using one computational system for the entire program,
whether it be for an undergrad or grad program. Here I make the case for
that system being R.
Let
me convince you!

title: The Full Stat Data Scientist
description: What is a full-stat data scientist?
contents:
I have been thinking about different data scientists, and I think we
need a new term for some: the full-stat data scientist.
No that is not a typo. Doubtless you have seen much about
full-stack data scientists, here we compare and contrast.
What is a
full-stack data scientist?
A full-stack data scientist is one who can code, do stats, define
metrics, etc and take an idea from concept through pipeline to database
design to building a dashboard.
They have all of the basic skills of a regular data scientist with
the added features of strong data engineering and software engineering
skills.
They are called full-stack because they work with the full
stack of data science tools.
One advantage of full-stack data scientists is that they can own the
data science product, from beginning to end.
They frequently come with computer science degrees, and have taken a
few stats courses.
What is a full-stat
data scientist?
A full-stat data scientist is a data scientist who can do
much of what a full-stack data scientist can, but is likely less skilled
in the data engineering realm.
They may not have as much experience in building dashboards or
pipelines, but they excel in the more quantitative areas. They may come
with advanced degrees in statistics, probability, and econometrics.
They model the business situation using whatever techniques are
required: analysis, stochastic modeling, simulation, optimization, game
theory, etc and determine which statistical techniques are required in
order to analyze the data based on the model.
They can adapt the techniques to the problem when needed, rather than
use inappropriate, but standard methodologies, or develop completely
novel approaches when needed.
They are deeply skeptical about data and find anomalies that no-one
else does and figures out what to do about them, and they care deeply
about uncertainty.

title: Ordinal Regression
contents:
The purpose of this project is to show how to do an ordinal regression in R.
Get started!

title: Beta Regression
contents:
The purpose of this project is to show how to do a beta regression in R using the awesome betareg package.
Get started!

title: Greta and Causact
description: Bayesian Models with Greta and Causact
contents:
The purpose of this project is to illustrate how to use the causact library to build some simple models. Causact allows you to create Bayesian models, and uses the greta library to do the computations. Well, not really - greta just sets them up, and uses TensorFlow underneath.
The cool thing is with causact you can describe your model as a graph, like this: 
and it automatically generates the greta code which you can run to get estimates of everything.
Get started!
More stuff to come soon about:
- multilevel models
- priors
- posterior predictive distributions.
